definition:
An algebra $A$ over a graded ring $B$ is *graded* if it is itself a
graded ring and a graded module over $B$ such that
$$A^p \cdot A^q \subseteq A^{p+q}$$ where $A^i$, $i \in \mathbb{N}$, are
submodules of $A$. More generally, one can replace $\mathbb{N}$ by a
monoid or semigroup $G$. In which case, $A$ is called a $G$-graded
algebra. A graded algebra then is the same thing as an
$\mathbb{N}$-graded algebra.

Examples of graded algebras include the polynomial ring $k[X]$ being an
$\mathbb{N}$-graded $k$-algebra, and the exterior algebra.
